trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of alcohol consumption on adult social drinkers' liking of snack foods
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Evaluating the impact of consuming a moderate dose of alcohol on the liking and characteristics of different snack foods: a pilot randomised crossover trial

interventions.interventions:
Participants will be provided with 30g of alcohol (in the form of wine) on each of the two testing evening. Participants will have 15 minutes to consume the wine. A randomly allocated set of snacks (intervention or control) will then be provided 30 minutes after the end of alcohol consumption. The washout period between testing evenings (i.e. the provision of different snacks) is a minimum of one week.
Intervention: Uncommon snacks and dip
Participants will be provided with a set of less commonly eaten savoury food snacks after drinking the moderate dose of alcohol and will consume the snacks until they are comfortably full. Participants will be asked to rate their liking of the uncommon snacks and their characteristics.
interventions.comparator:
Control: Common snacks and dip
Participants will be provided with a set of commonly eaten savoury food snacks after drinking the moderate dose of alcohol and will consume the snacks until they are comfortably full. Participants will be asked to rate their liking of the common snacks and their characteristics.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Subjective ratings of the five characteristics (flavour, texture, mouth-feel, liking of the appearance and overall liking) of the food snacks, as measured by five 9-Point Hedonic Scales.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At three hours after the commencement of each testing evening.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: % Breath alcohol concentration as measured by an Alcolimit breathalyser.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 30, 45, 60 90, 120 and 180 minutes after consuming a moderate alcohol dose using Area under the curve.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Blood glucose, insulin and lipids, as collected by blood samples via cannula and measured by serum and plasma assays.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, then 0, 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, 120 and 180 minutes after consuming a moderate dose of alcohol using Area under the curve.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: This study is recruiting healthy 18 to 65 year old adult social drinkers with a Body Mass Index between 18.5kg/m2 to 30kg/m2 who like and eat savoury snacks such as crisps, nuts, biscuits and dips
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
Volunteers who have any of the following of the key exclusion criteria will be unable to participate in this study:
1. Consume six or more standard drinks on more than two separate occasions in the last month and less than 4 or more than 64 standard drinks per month. 2. Diagnosed with Type 1 or Type 2 Diabetes or that on screening, not have a random blood glucose reading above 8.0mmol/L 3. Pregnant or breastfeeding 4. Smoker 5. Unable to tolerate lactose (i.e. have lactose intolerance but not using lactase tablets to manage symptoms) 6. Allergic or sensitive to nuts or nut products (nut allergy) 7. Allergic to cows milk protein (milk allergy) 8. Allergic to egg protein (egg allergy) 9. Allergic to wheat (wheat allergy) 10. Allergic to sesame seeds (sesame allergy) 11. Allergic to fish and crustaceans (fish allergy and crustacean allergy) 12. Intolerant to gluten (coeliac disease) 13. Vegan or unable to eat foods with dairy and egg products 14. Have dietary restrictions, such as for cultural reasons (i.e. requiring Halal and/or Kosher foods) 15. Have an implanted cardiac defibrillator, active prostheses, cardiac pacemaker or have open wounds on hands and/or feet 16. Currently dieting to lose weight and/or have an eating disorder

trial_design.concealment: Allocation is concealed in opaque envelopes
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software
trial_design.statisticalmethods:
This is a pilot randomised crossover trial study so no sample size calculation has been used. A sample of 20 participants has been estimated to provide sufficient data for power calculations for potential larger studies.
The statistical analysis plan is expected to include Area Under the Curve, Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) and paired sample t-tests.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Nutrition, Dietetics & Food Monash University, School of Clinical Sciences Level 1, 264 Ferntree Gully Road Notting Hill VIC 3168

fundingsource.fundingaddress: 461 South Rd Regency Park SA 5010 Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
This study will investigate the impact of consuming alcohol on the liking and characteristics of two different sets of savoury food snacks (newly developed food snacks, uncommon food snacks and common food snacks).
Participants in this study will attend the study on two testing evenings and will be randomly allocated to a different set of snacks on each evening. Participants will drink a moderate dose of alcohol and then consume the provided snacks until they are comfortably full. They will be asked to complete questionnaires on their liking of the different snack foods including the flavour, appearance, mouth-feel and texture. Other data that will be collected from participants on each testing evening include multiple appetite and hunger ratings, blood samples collected to observe changes in biomarkers and breath alcohol concentration measurements.
The results from this study will assist with the potential development of new food snacks to have when consuming alcohol for social drinkers.
